channel.title: Hi again #2

item.title: Hi again #2
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:6, topic:541100”]Minimum width can be used to prevent fudge-ups, for mobile support he should be including a different style depending on browser.[/quote]You should be supporting different devices with responsive design, not multiple stylesheets… Also lol it’s 2014, “mobile support” doesn’t mean anything with the massive number of heterogeneous devices we have now.

Read full topic

item.title: Hi again #2
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

Technically any prefixes such as -o-, -webkit-, etc… are not part of the CSS spec and so they can be considered as just support for browsers that haven’t fully supported the spec yet. But to support older browsers that can still support those new CSS3 effects, it is common practice to leave all the prefixes in so you get that extra browser support. With something like CSS, deprecated properties are totally fine anyway since they won’t have much of an effect on the script itself.

You also have JavaScript options such as using Modernizr.js.

Read full topic

item.title: Hi again #2
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“John, post:7, topic:541100”]I don’t recall ever using or . As for list tags what’s wrong with it? In fact, I don’t know of any alternatives to using it that exist. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/li
I made the minimal width set to 1240px because I was using percentages within margins. If the page was resized, after a certain point a few elements would reposition themselves.
I was told that -moz- and -o- are now deprecated in CSS3. Some of the -webkit- options such as shaking an image still only work in Chrome, but others such as [tt]-webkit-transition: background 2s ease-in-out;[/tt] work flawlessly in all three browsers I’ve tested it on (Firefox, Chrome, Safari).
I didn’t use any images, everything was styled using CSS. If you’re talking about the computer next to the DesignHub text, that’s Font-Awesome.

Thanks for the feedback.

EDIT: In regards to suggesting I not use , I’d normally agree to not italicize without using CSS but according to Font-Awesome’s examples, http://fortawesome.github.io/Font-Awesome/examples/[/quote]

  • was a typo! I meant lol :D

    I did not hear anything about -moz- and -o- being deprecated so idk :S
    Idk why Font-Awesome is using the tags lol, little weird.

    • Read full topic

item.title: Hi again #2
item.dc:creator: @Flame3 John
item.description:
@Flame3 wrote:

I don’t recall ever using or . As for list tags what’s wrong with it? In fact, I don’t know of any alternatives to using it that exist. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/li
I made the minimal width set to 1240px because I was using percentages within margins. If the page was resized, after a certain point a few elements would reposition themselves.
I was told that -moz- and -o- are now deprecated in CSS3. Some of the -webkit- options such as shaking an image still only work in Chrome, but others such as [tt]-webkit-transition: background 2s ease-in-out;[/tt] work flawlessly in all three browsers I’ve tested it on (Firefox, Chrome, Safari).
I didn’t use any images, everything was styled using CSS. If you’re talking about the computer next to the DesignHub text, that’s Font-Awesome.

Thanks for the feedback.

EDIT: In regards to suggesting I not use , I’d normally agree to not italicize without using CSS but according to Font-Awesome’s examples, http://fortawesome.github.io/Font-Awesome/examples/

Read full topic

item.title: Hi again #2
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“Arcik, post:5, topic:541100”]You don’t need [size=8pt]type=“text/css”[/size] and how comes you only added it to the style.css and not font-awesome.min.css? lol

You shouldn’t be using [size=8pt],

  • ,
    • [/size] etc., because you’re not suppose to style with HTML instead use CSS instead. There is also a tag if you want to place your content inside that

    Why are you setting the min-width to 1240px? Wouldn’t that just mess up on smaller browsers?
    You should also add
    [size=8pt]-o-
    -moz-
    -ms-    [/size]
    and any other browser stuff alongside any CSS3 stuff you’re using (Since you’re only using -webkit- for that transition).

    Enough of that above crap, I like your design, are the images yours?
    Can’t wait to see the finished product! :)[/quote]Minimum width can be used to prevent fuck-ups, for mobile support he should be including a different style depending on browser. As for and I would argue they are fine but is now obsolete.

    Read full topic

item.title: Hi again #2
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

You don’t need [size=8pt]type=“text/css”[/size] and how comes you only added it to the style.css and not font-awesome.min.css? lol

You shouldn’t be using [size=8pt], , [/size] etc., because you’re not suppose to style with HTML instead use CSS instead. There is also a tag if you want to place your content inside that

Why are you setting the min-width to 1240px? Wouldn’t that just mess up on smaller browsers?
You should also add
[size=8pt]-o-
-moz-
-ms-[/size]
and any other browser stuff alongside any CSS3 stuff you’re using (Since you’re only using -webkit- for that transition).

Enough of that above crap, I like your design, are the images yours?
Can’t wait to see the finished product!

Read full topic

[/code] [code=css]html { width: 100%; min-width: 1240px; } body { background-color: #ecf0f1; width: 100%; } a { text-decoration: none; color: #ecf0f1; transition: all 250ms linear; -webkit-transition: background 2s ease-in-out; } nav a:hover { color: #FFF; } nav a:active { color: #CCC; } nav { width: 100%; height: 30px; margin: -8px -8px 0 -8px; background-color: #34495e; color: #ecf0f1; font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif; } #leftnav { float: left; line-height: 180%; margin: 0 0 0 50px; width: auto; } #rightnav { margin: 0 50px 0 0; } #rightnav li { list-style: none; } #rightnav li a { list-style: none; float: right; line-height: 180%; text-align: center; margin: 0 0 0 0; padding-left: 20px; padding-right: 20px; width: auto; display: inline-block; transition: all 250ms linear; -webkit-transition: background .25s ease-in-out; } #rightnav li a:hover { background-color: #DDD; color: #34495e; } header { text-align: center; float: right; background-color: #375B80; width: 100%; height: 75px; margin: 0 8px; font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif; color: #FFF; } header #info { margin-left: 75px; line-height: 380%; float: left; font-size: 18px; padding-right: inherit; } header i { padding: 5px; } header a { text-decoration: none; color: #E0E0E0; } header a:hover { color: #FCFCFC; } header li { margin-top: -16px; font-size: 20px; line-height: -10%; padding: 20px; width: auto; display: inline-block; } .alert { border-radius: 9px; margin: 80px auto 0 auto; width: 650px; height: 30px; line-height: 180%; text-align: center; font-size: 15px; color: #ecf0f1; background-color: #16a085; text-decoration: none; } .alert a { text-decoration: none; color: #FFF; font-weight: bold; text-transform: uppercase; } #placeholder { height: 595px; } footer { background-color: #375B80; width: 100%; height: 150px; margin: 0 -8px -8px; bottom: 0; } footer #footerleft { float: left; width: auto; } footer ul { list-style-type: none; margin: -15px 50px 0 0; padding: 0; display: inline-block; *display: inline; zoom: 1; } footer li { margin-left: 60px; } footer li a { text-decoration: none; color: #FFF; } footer li a:hover { font-weight: bold; } footer h3 { color: #ecf0f1; padding: 0; margin: 30px 0 4px -10px; } footer #footerright { float: right; width: auto; color: #ecf0f1; font-size: 18px; vertical-align: top; } footer #footerright #info { margin: 3px 50px 0 0; width: 500px; height: 100px; text-align: justify; } footer #sitename { text-align: center; font-size: 25px; font-family: Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif; margin: 14px auto 0 0; } [/code]
